STATE OF MICHIGAN
GRETCHEN WHITMER DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES ROBERT GORDON
GOVERNOR LANSING DIRECTOR
October 17, 2019
Jennifer Vasilovski
Family and Community Services-Macomb
42140 Van Dyke Ave, Suite 110
Sterling Heights, MI 48314
RE: License #: CB500316267
Investigation #: 2019C0219035
Family and Community Services-Macomb
Dear Ms. Vasilovski:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
FOR CWL ONLY
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the ISEP and
your contract.
611 W. OTTAWA  P.O. BOX 30664  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov/lara  517-335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the local office at (248) 975-5053.
Sincerely,
Christopher Barr, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
4th Floor, Suite 4B
51111 Woodward Avenue
Pontiac, MI 48342
(248) 860-2282
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CB500316267
Investigation #: 2019C0219035
Complaint Receipt Date: 04/30/2019
Investigation Initiation Date: 04/30/2019
Report Due Date: 06/29/2019
Licensee Name: Family & Community Services Inc
Licensee Address: 42140 Van Dyke Ave, Suite 110
Sterling Heights, MI 48317
Licensee Telephone #: (330) 297-7027
Administrator: Jennifer Vasilovski, Designee
Licensee Designee: Jennifer Vasilovski, Designee
Name of Facility: Family and Community Services-Macomb
Facility Address: 42140 Van Dyke Ave, Suite 110
Sterling Heights, MI 48314
Facility Telephone #: (586) 726-2988
Original Issuance Date: 11/20/2012
License Status: REGULAR
Effective Date: 05/09/2019
Expiration Date: 05/08/2021
Capacity: Unknown
Program Type: CHILD PLACING AGENCY, PRIVATE
1

II. ALLEGATION(S)
Violation
Established?
Child placing agency is using an outside source for billing which is Yes
leaking confidential information to the internet.
Additional Findings No
III. METHODOLOGY
04/30/2019 Special Investigation Intake
2019C0219035
04/30/2019 Special Investigation Initiated - Telephone
04/30/2019 Contact - Document Received
Emails received and exchanged with DCWL central office,
MDHHS analyst, and complainant.
05/01/2019 Contact - Document Received
Emails exchanged with director and consultant 2.
05/01/2019 Contact - Document Received
Email sent to consultant 2.
05/02/2019 Contact - Document Received
Email from director.
05/02/2019 Contact - Document Sent
Emails exchanged with MDHHS analyst.
05/02/2019 Contact - Document Received
Emails exchanged with director, director 2 and consultant 2.
05/15/2019 Contact - Document Received
Email from director notifying that director 2 will be taking over
during the director's maternity leave.
05/20/2019 Contact - Document Sent
Emails exchanged with director, director 2, and consultant 2.
06/05/2019 Contact - Document Received
Received email from director.
2

07/02/2019 Contact - Document Sent
Emails exchanged with director 2 and consultant 2 with the
director copied.
09/09/2019 Contact - Document Received
Emails exchanged with director, director 2, and consultant 2.
09/19/2019 Contact – Document Sent
Emails exchanged with director and consultant 2.
09/27/2019 Contact – Document Sent
Emails exchanged with director and consultant 2.
10/07/2019 Contact – Document Sent
Emails exchanged with director, director 2, and consultant 2.
10/15/2019 Contact – Document Sent
Emails exchanged with director, privacy and security analyst, and
consultant 2.
10/17/2019 Exit Conference
ALLEGATION: Child placing agency is using an outside source for billing which is
leaking confidential information to the internet.
INVESTIGATION:
Names have been coded in this report, including within quoted text.
DCWL director forwarded an email chain regarding this complaint on 04/30/19.
The email states the following:
Essentially it appears that both agencies use a third-party website to process
or track their billing. The website is Cair Solutions, see below, and the
information entered into “myadoptionportal” includes confidential information
about families and MDHHS children. A foster parent reported to MDHHS
yesterday that he saw an article related to this website on Facebook, that he
was able to pull up a report that listed confidential information about FCS
Macomb, and that by doing a Google search on a foster parent’s name was
able to pull up the “myadoptionportal” PDF report that listed confidential
information about families and kids.
The Wayne DHHS analyst was able to do the Google search herself and
received the same report. She may be a person to contact for information if
3

needed. The concern is that both agencies appear to be using this website,
and it is resulting in a violation of confidentiality of protected information.
Agency director email dated 05/01/19 states the following:
Yesterday around 2:30ish we were notified that somehow one of our internal
billing reports was able to be located by an outside party via Google.
Currently, we utilize an internal database system - Cairs Solutions (My
Adoption Portal - MAPS) to log all of our internal information including our
foster parent information, the children’s information, billing, stipends, clothing
allowances, mileage, etc. Our foster parents do not have access to this. We
also use this with our international/domestic families whom do have access to
this portal to upload their documents for their home studies, etc. including
marriage certificates, birth certificates, etc. Within one hour of being notified of
this issue we contacted MAPS and they restricted access within 3 minutes.
This program is a secured program that is protected by multiple firewalls, an
individual cannot get into their internal network to the production data without
going through multiple layers/firewalls. For example, in order for us or our
adoptive parents to get into the program a username/password is required.
What happened in this situation is that one of our billing reports was being
used in their “testing environment” and somehow the security feature for this
malfunctioned, allowing public access. Per the CEO at MAPS, in order for
someone to have gained access to this they would’ve had to type in the name
of the family + the name of the testing environment, which is not public
knowledge. We don’t even know that information so I’m not sure how an
outside person would know that. Also, according to MAPS only four people
gained access to this (as they can and did track the IP addresses) – one was
the State of Michigan, one was the person who initially accessed the
information, one was us (FCS) and one was another party whom clicked the
link whom I’m assuming may be the person who forwarded the information to
you. I asked MAPS how long they believe this was accessible to the public
and they are under the belief that it was a short period of time as from what
they can see Google indexed this very recently.
All this being said, I asked them what would be done to ensure something like
this does not occur again. They have indicated that they will no longer be
putting billing reports into testing environments and would be placing them
into a “privileged only” category where only certain people are granted
access. According to MAPS, this did not affect other agencies or other billing
reports, just this one. This billing report included the foster parents
name/address, child’s name, SACWIS person ID#, DOC level and placement
dates.
Director emailed to request a copy of the entire list of families observed on the
website on 05/02/19 and reported the following update:
4

I only have the screenshot that consultant 2 sent me and the link is now
restricted. I did request it from the computer data program but because it was
a “testing environment” as soon as they restricted the access they also lost
the information in the testing environment (I guess, I’m not super-computer
savvy) since it was not a full report and only a sample.
Also, I did call the compliance office however, they told me that because we
are not DHHS they do not deal with us. I explained that we are a PAFC that
was contracted through DHHS but they said that doesn’t matter. Anyhow, that
doesn’t really seem right to me so I’m going to send in the DCH 1422 form as
outlined in the policy: APL 68E-130 BREACH, SECURITY INCIDENT OR
IMPERMISSIBLE USE OR DISCLOSURE, to the Privacy Security e-mail and
go from there. From how I’m reading this policy, once I send this document in
they determine the level of risk of harm under the HIPAA Act which
determines if we have to notify the individuals of the breach. While a DOC in
and of itself doesn’t verify any health breach (could be educational) in my
opinion a SED is directly a result of mental health issues so that would fall
under the HIPAA Guideline. I will send this document in when completed (I
have attached for your viewing) – hopefully by tomorrow as the one question I
need to answer is how many people were affected but I can’t do that
accurately without the full report.
If I don’t get a response from the compliance office in a reasonable period of
time as we are not DHHS I will follow the HIPAA Guideline and notify the
effected parties.
The Wayne DHHS analyst confirmed via email, on 05/02/19, that she was initially
able to click the link when this information came up. She tracked a couple of families
back to the agency. When asked for some clarifying information, the analyst was not
able to connect via the link any longer.
Director emailed the following update on 05/20/19:
As outlined in DHHS policy APL-68E-130 I called DHHS Privacy Security on
5-2-19 to notify them of the breach, the woman on the phone told me that
because we were not DHHS (even though were a contracted PAFC) they did
not care and wouldn’t look into this issue. I didn’t think that was accurate so I
also followed up with an e-mail on 5-3-19. On 5-15-19 I received an e-mail
back from the Privacy and Compliance Analyst indicating “We have reviewed
the incident but have not completed an assessment yet.” I did ask if there was
a time frame for receiving an assessment and this was the response “Every
incident is different – it depends on the severity, data, risk, and other
incidents. HIPAA incidents must be resolved within 60 days, but they don’t
usually get that far.”
5

That being said, we are just waiting for their risk assessment and how they
are requesting we move forward.
Director emailed on 06/05/19 that they still had not received an update from DHHS
Privacy Security.
Director emailed on 09/09/19 that they had never received a risk assessment from
privacy security but did send a letter to the individual this affected (per HIPAA
Guidelines) within the appropriate timeframe.
Director provided the following updates on 09/27/2019:
Director reported that Cair Solutions is a “computer database system in which
we enter in our families, dates of placement, per diems, etc. in order to be
able to generate our internal billing reports, monitor our internal finances, etc.
In addition, families within our international and domestic adoption programs
can make their own login and upload their documents needed for their
adoption home study (i.e. marriage license, driver’s license, etc.) for us to
have access too. This is all password protected.” The Director verified that
Cair Solutions did not, and does not, have access to MiSACWIS. In regard to
notifications to those affected by the breach, the director noted that they sent
a letter to the individual whose medical information was breeched (SED
Waiver child) via the HIPAA protocol. Per HIPAA we had to notify anyone
whom has health information breeched within 60 days. The 60th day in this
case was on 7-1-19 and we sent the letter on that date as we hadn’t heard
back from the DHHS Security Breech department with regards to any
direction. We did not send letters regarding the other individuals with DOC’s
as a DOC in and of itself does not necessarily pertain to physical or mental
health, it can be geared toward education or behavior.
Follow up communication with director dated 10/07/19 states the following update
was provided in regard to feedback from MDHHS Privacy and Security:
We sent the initial e-mail on 05/03/2019 and did not receive a response. I
sent a follow up on 05/15/2019 and the Privacy and Compliance Analyst
responded that they have not completed an assessment yet. I asked if there
was a time frame for this and he said typically 60-days, but it usually doesn’t
get to that. We never heard anything else, so I followed up again on
06/07/2019 because the 60th day was approaching (07/01/2019) and I was
going on maternity leave and wanted to have this wrapped up. We did not
get a response to that e-mail and hadn’t heard anything by the 60th day so
we sent out the letter to our foster parent per HIPAA guidelines on the 60th
day.
6

Privacy and Security analyst emailed the following on 10/15/2019 stating:
We completed the incident below as low risk, with no notice required to the
individuals. HIPAA is not applicable to the data and the incident did not meet
the breach criteria of the Michigan Identity Theft Protection Act – the two
regulations with notice requirements. Even if they had been applicable, the
incident still appears to be low risk per the situation.
A copy of the document alleged to have been subject to this breach was provided by
the agency and was found to be labeled, “Foster Care Billing Report.” It was dated
04/03/2017 with a time of 10:31:24AM. The information contained on this report was
“Family,” “Family Address,” “Child,” “Age Group,” “DOC Level,” “Case No.,” “No of
Days,” “Placement Date,” and “End Date.” There were 5 families identified and 8
children.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12211 Privacy safeguard.
(1) An agency shall safeguard the privacy of a child and his or
her family.
ANALYSIS: There is clear evidence in this case to demonstrate
noncompliance as foster parent information and children’s
names were briefly available to unauthorized users. Although
the third-party provider is contracted by the agency, it is the
agency who is ultimately responsible for compliance with
licensing rules.
CONSULTATION: The agency should consider discussing the use of third-party
contractors with their assigned MDHHS contract analyst to
review and for potential contractual concerns.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
7

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Upon receipt of an approved corrective action plan no change to the current license
is recommended.
10/17/2019
________________________________________
Christopher Barr Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
October 17, 2019
________________________________________
Linda Tansil Date
Area Manager
8
